com.joliciel.talismane.tokeniser

Class TokenSequence

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.AbstractCollection<E>
      • java.util.AbstractList<E>
        • java.util.ArrayList<Token>
          • com.joliciel.talismane.tokeniser.TokenSequence
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Iterable<Token>, java.util.Collection<Token>, java.util.List<Token>, java.util.RandomAccess
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    PretokenisedSequence

    public class TokenSequence
extends java.util.ArrayList<Token>
implements java.io.Serializable
    A sequence of tokens. Note: by default, List iteration and associated methods will only return non-whitespace tokens. For a list that includes whitespace tokens, use the listWithWhiteSpace() method.

    Only a single attribute of a given key can be added per token. If two attribute placeholders overlap and assign the same key, the one with the lower start index is privileged for all tokens, and the other one is skipped for all tokens. If they have the same start index, the one with the higher end index is priveleged for all tokens, and the other one is skipped for all tokens.
    Author:
    Assaf Urieli
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      Finalise a reconstructed token sequence so that all of the indexes are correct on the component tokens, and so that all attributes are correctly assigned to component tokens from the containing sentence.

      • getTokenSplits

        public java.util.List<java.lang.Integer> getTokenSplits()
        Returns the token splits represented by this token sequence, where each integer represents the symbol immediately following a token split.

      • listWithWhiteSpace

        public java.util.List<Token> listWithWhiteSpace()
        A list of tokens that includes white space tokens.

      • finalise

        public void finalise()
        Finalise a reconstructed token sequence so that all of the indexes are correct on the component tokens, and so that all attributes are correctly assigned to component tokens from the containing sentence.

      • getScore

        public double getScore()
        The geometric mean of the tokeniser decisions. Note that only actual decisions made by a decision maker will be taken into account - any default decisions will not be included.

      • getUnderlyingAtomicTokenSequence

        public TokenisedAtomicTokenSequence getUnderlyingAtomicTokenSequence()
        Returns the tokenised atomic token sequence, generated by a tokeniser, from which this token sequence was initially inferred.

      • getAtomicTokenCount

        public int getAtomicTokenCount()
        The number of atomic tokens making up this token sequence (+1 for each empty token).

      • addToken

        public Token addToken(int start,
                      int end)
        Adds a token to the current sequence, using substring coordinates from the associated sentence. If a token already exists with this exact start and end, will not perform any action. Any other existing token whose start < end and end > start will be removed.

      • addEmptyToken

        public Token addEmptyToken(int position)
        Add an empty token at a certain position in the sentence.

      • removeEmptyToken

        public void removeEmptyToken(Token emptyToken)
                      throws TalismaneException
        Remove an empty token from this token sequence.
        Throws:
        TalismaneException - if an attempt is made to remove a non-empty token

      • cleanSlate

        public void cleanSlate()
        Cleans out any collections of modifications, so that any modifications after this clean slate can be viewed.
        If run before applying filters, will enable the client code to detect any tokens added by the filters.
        See Also:
        getTokensAdded()

      • getTokensAdded

        public java.util.List<Token> getTokensAdded()
        Returns the tokens added since the last clean slate.
        See Also:

        public Sentence getSentence()
        The sentence object on which this token sequence was built, allowing us to identify its location in the source text.
